week1_picks_results.stay_away: MHJTIME vs Father Time: MHJTIME won 182.8-165.06

essay:
Sixty-nine point nine. That’s not a margin of victory — that’s the kind of number that makes the group chat go silent for three full minutes before someone types “bro” in all lowercase. The Boonist Monks — preseason dead last, the franchise we described as “could win it all or retire it all” — just obliterated Burden of Etienne-y Woody 168.7 to 98.8, and somehow that wasn’t even the most interesting thing that happened in Week 2.

Because while @GauchoTrain was busy conducting a one-sided demolition derby, MHJTIME quietly put up 182.8 points — the highest single-week score of the young season — and the group chat barely flinched. Malik Nabers exploded for 34.2. Ja’Marr Chase added 30.5. Jayden Daniels pitched in 19.7. We called that WR trio “historic” in the preseason, and two weeks in, the word feels undersized. The problem? After losing Week 1 with 142.62 despite doing everything right, MHJTIME is only 1-1 — and leads the league in total points at 325.4. That’s the dynasty equivalent of batting .400 and your team being .500.

The symmetry of suffering is almost poetic this week. Remember how MHJTIME scored 142 in Week 1 and lost to the one opponent who went off? Father Time just lived the exact same nightmare — dropped 165.06 behind Jared Goff’s 33.96 and Roquan Smith’s 26.5, and still lost because MHJTIME’s ceiling is apparently located in outer space. The preseason essay warned that the chat would love Father Time’s random 180-point weeks and ignore the rest. At 0-2 with 165.06 this week, the rest is all there is.

Then there’s the free fall. One week ago, the Sleeping Giants sat atop these power rankings — the feel-good story, the aging roster that refused to age, Derrick Henry’s 28.7-point proclamation that the clock hadn’t struck midnight yet. Seven days later? A 32.66-point loss to General Ken-obi, a kicker (Brandon Aubrey at 24.5) leading the scoring column, and a six-spot tumble to seventh. We said they were playing on borrowed time. Turns out the loan shark came early.

The real story of Week 2 might be what’s crystallizing at the top. Five teams sit at 2-0 — the Boonist Monks, Kittler on the Roof, General Ken-obi, the Legion of Bouz, and Rasheeing the Scene. Five more are winless. Only MHJTIME and the Sleeping Giants occupy the messy middle at 1-1, and one of them has more points than anyone. The league has split cleanly into haves and have-nots after fourteen days, and the group chat’s power rankings discourse has already reached “well actually” levels of intensity.

General Ken-obi — your preseason number one, the team everyone measured themselves against — is quietly doing exactly what preseason favorites are supposed to do. Drake Maye’s 26.3, Kenneth Walker’s 18.3, CeeDee Lamb’s 16.7. No drama. No fireworks. Just wins. Two of them.

Two weeks down, twelve to go. The preseason bottom-dweller is the new number one. The preseason darling is licking its wounds at seventh. The league’s best scorer can’t buy a second win. And somewhere in the group chat, someone is already typing a four-paragraph essay about why their 0-2 team is “actually fine.”

Dynasty is chaos theory with a waiver wire. Act accordingly.

rankings.blurb: Two weeks ago you were dead last in the preseason rankings. Now you’re sitting at number one with a 2-0 record and the second-highest point total in the league at 313.1. The Week 2 performance wasn’t subtle: Lamar Jackson dropped 26.3, James Cook erupted for 25.0, and linebacker Daiyan Henley contributed a startling 23.5 from the IDP slot. The result? A 69.9-point blowout of Burden — the largest margin of victory this season by a country mile. We said your team could win it all or retire it all. Through two weeks, the retirement party has been indefinitely postponed. Jaxon Smith-Njigba (14.3) and Tyreek Hill (13.9) added supporting roles, and at 27.2 years average age, every week feels like playing with house money. @GauchoTrain’s side bets in the group chat are getting louder, the receipts are piling up, and the league’s most prolific instigator is becoming the protagonist. Enjoy it — the schedule gets real in Week 3.

The defending champion just keeps doing defending-champion things. Jonathan Taylor’s 28.5 was the kind of quiet monster game that doesn’t trend in the group chat but wins you weeks — and weeks are what matter. Puka Nacua added 23.6, Tucker Kraft chipped in 21.4, and suddenly the roster we said had a drywall ceiling is outperforming teams with marble ones. You beat Noble FFT 146.14 to 129.38 — the closest game of the week, which tells you exactly how dominant the top of this league was. Runner-up in 2022, runner-up in 2023, champion in 2024, and now a quiet 2-0 start in 2025. The pattern is undeniable: you show up, you grind, and you let flashier rosters implode around you. Tony Pollard managed 9.2 from the flex — still not spectacular, still not hurting you. The chat will keep making Pollard jokes. You’ll keep winning.

Remember when you dropped from first to fifth in Week 1 despite winning? The preseason favorite continues to do preseason-favorite things — beating the teams you’re supposed to beat and doing it convincingly. Drake Maye’s 26.3 was a legitimate statement game at quarterback, Kenneth Walker added 18.3, and the supporting cast of CeeDee Lamb (16.7), Saquon Barkley (16.4), and Fred Warner (16.0) provided the kind of depth that makes other managers jealous. The 32.66-point demolition of the Sleeping Giants was no schedule gift — you took the Week 1 number-one team and made them look ordinary. You’re 2-0 with 287.3 total points, and the roster that could headline Coachella is finally sounding like a headliner. The taxi squad debates have been replaced by a much simpler narrative: the franchise everyone measures themselves against is measuring up just fine.

Amon-Ra St. Brown scored 34.7 points this week. Thirty-four point seven. That’s the highest individual performance in the entire league — the kind of number that silences the group chat for a beat before the fire emojis start flying. Dak Prescott added 22.14 from the quarterback spot, Christian McCaffrey chipped in 19.7, and you dispatched Ghastly Grayskull by 46.46 points. Since winning the inaugural title in 2022, you’ve been stuck in the middle — that was the preseason narrative, anyway. Two-and-oh doesn’t feel like the middle. We kept saying your Voltron receivers needed a tight end with a pulse to compete, but when ARSB is single-handedly outscoring entire rosters, maybe the pulse is optional. The 2022 champion looks like a championship contender again, and the rest of the league is starting to notice.

Don’t let the three-spot drop fool you — a win is a win, and you’ve got two of them. The 135.32-point outing against Chudders wasn’t your flashiest work, but De’Von Achane’s 22.2, Travis Etienne’s 15.9, and Bucky Irving’s 15.1 proved your RB room is a legitimate three-headed monster. The interesting wrinkle: Josh Allen — the QB1 who torched Noble for 38.76 last week — didn’t crack your top five scorers this week, and you still won comfortably. That’s the kind of roster depth that makes the ‘weekly thrill ride’ label from the preseason actually feel like a compliment. You’re 2-0 with 279.4 points, which is fifth but close enough to first to keep the chat buzzing. The WR room is still a meme waiting to happen, but when your running backs are dropping 53 combined points, who needs elite receivers?

Here’s the number that should terrify the rest of this league: 325.4. That’s your total points through two weeks — more than any other team, including all five of the 2-0 squads. Malik Nabers went nuclear with 34.2, Ja’Marr Chase added a casual 30.5, and Jayden Daniels contributed 19.7. We called that WR trio ‘historic’ in the preseason. After back-to-back performances of 142.62 and 182.8, the adjective feels conservative. The 182.8 this week was the highest single-game score of the season — and it barely felt like news because the rest of your roster is so loaded. Chuba Hubbard added 16.2, proving the RB room isn’t the total disaster we predicted. The only thing standing between you and a 2-0 record is Week 1’s scheduling coin flip. You’re the most dangerous 1-1 team in Jailyard history.

From the top of the mountain to the gift shop at base camp. One week ago you were the feel-good story — Derrick Henry’s 28.7-point explosion carrying you to a first-place ranking that made the group chat reconsider every preseason take. Then Week 2 happened. Henry didn’t even crack your top five scorers this week. Your leading scorer was kicker Brandon Aubrey at 24.5 — and when your kicker is your best player, the ‘borrowed time’ narrative from the preseason starts sounding less like a hot take and more like a prophecy. Jalen Hurts managed just 10.54, Keenan Allen added 14.6, and the 32.66-point loss to General Ken-obi was the kind of defeat that resets expectations entirely. You’re 1-1 with 270.2 total points — respectable, not dominant. The Island of Misfit WR1s didn’t sink, but the tide just came in.

We need to talk about the cruelest stat in the Jailyard right now: you’ve scored 285.7 points through two weeks and you’re 0-2. For context, that’s more total points than Rasheeing the Scene, who is sitting pretty at 2-0. Jared Goff went off for 33.96 this week, Roquan Smith dominated with 26.5 from the linebacker slot, and Davante Adams pitched in 19.6. You scored 165.06 and lost because MHJTIME decided to put up 182.8. Sound familiar? It should — MHJTIME lived this exact nightmare in Week 1, scoring 142.62 and losing to the one team that outscored them. The preseason essay said the chat would love your random 180-point weeks and ignore the rest. At 0-2, the rest keeps piling up. But 285.7 total points don’t lie — this record isn’t a reflection of your roster. It’s a scheduling vendetta.

Stuck at ninth for two straight weeks, and the preseason number two has to be asking: what happened? Jordan Love threw for 20.88, Bijan Robinson put up 18.3, and even IDP stud Brian Branch contributed 18.0 from the defensive backfield. You scored 129.38 — a perfectly respectable total that happened to run into the defending champion’s best game of the young season. Jonathan Taylor’s 28.5 and Puka Nacua’s 23.6 simply outclassed your supporting cast. The scariest backfield in the league isn’t scary enough when the rest of the roster can’t keep pace. We said Bijan and Breece were gods but gods need a supporting cast. Two weeks into 2025, the audition for that supporting cast is not going well.

The rebuild was never supposed to be pretty, and through two weeks, it’s living down to that billing. Jahmyr Gibbs led the way with 17.9 and Justin Herbert added 17.78, but neither number is the kind of week-winner that turns 0-2 into 1-1. The loss to Rasheeing by 22.54 wasn’t embarrassing — 112.78 points from a roster this young is honestly defensible — but the war chest of draft picks isn’t scoring points yet. Emeka Egbuka, the Week 1 hero who debuted with 21.6, came back to earth with 10.9 this week. One week it looked like the rebuild was six months ahead of schedule; the next week it looked like the original timeline. Keep icing those trade offers — the window between patience and irrelevance is narrowing, but two firsts in the next two drafts still make this the most interesting rebuilding project in the league.

Moving up one spot while going 0-2 is the dynasty equivalent of getting a participation trophy — technically progress, practically meaningless. J.K. Dobbins led your scorers with 15.0, Quentin Johnston added 14.4, and your 109.78 total was third-worst in the league this week. The 46.46-point loss to the Legion of Bouz wasn’t even competitive after the first quarter — Amon-Ra St. Brown alone (34.7) nearly matched your top three scorers combined (43.3). We said your pick stash was bigger than your WR room. The WR room just put up Quentin Johnston and Deebo Samuel (13.9) as its headliners, so the math still checks out. After the 9.72-point C.J. Stroud dud in Week 1, another week where your quarterback didn’t crack the top five is becoming a pattern the chat won’t let you forget.

Ninety-eight point eight. That’s the lowest score in the Jailyard this week, the lowest score of the entire season so far, and the kind of number that makes the group chat wince instead of roast. Justin Jefferson — your top-three overall dynasty asset, the franchise cornerstone, the player we said could only carry you so far — scored 9.6 points. For the second straight week, Jefferson wasn’t your leading scorer. George Pickens led with 15.3, followed by Kyler Murray at 15.0. When a trade acquisition outscores your franchise player two weeks running, the alarm bells aren’t just ringing — they’re playing a full symphony. The 69.9-point loss to the Boonist Monks was the worst beatdown of the season. We flagged the QB roulette and the RB triage unit in the preseason. At 0-2 with 219.1 total points, the Jefferson trade rumors aren’t rumors anymore — they’re a business plan.

confessionals.text: Preseason twelfth. Dead last. 'Could win it all or retire it all,' they said. I just won by 69.9 points. Lamar went off. Cook went off. Even the linebacker nobody’s heard of went off. I’m sitting at number one in the power rankings and the group chat still thinks this is a fluke. Let them. I’ve been posting receipts for two weeks straight and I’m not running out of ink.

I scored 165 points. One hundred and sixty-five. Goff had 34. Roquan had 26. Davante had 20. In any other matchup, in any other week, I’m celebrating. But I drew MHJTIME — the same MHJTIME who complained about bad luck in Week 1. Now I understand. I deeply, profoundly understand. I’m starting a support group. Meetings are Mondays.

I have the most points in the entire league. Three hundred and twenty-five. Malik Nabers just scored 34.2. Chase had 30.5. I put up 182 this week. And I’m 1-1. Somebody explain to me how the team that scores the most points in the Jailyard is sitting at .500. Actually, don’t explain it. I lived it in Week 1. The schedule gods are using me as a cautionary tale.

One week. That’s how long I got to be number one. Seven days of glory. Then General Ken-obi walked in, my kicker outscored Jalen Hurts, and Derrick Henry apparently took the week off. Last week I was reading my preseason essay out loud to Henry through my phone. This week I’m just staring at it. Maybe he can’t hear me after all.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: The Boonist Monks were ranked twelfth in the preseason and are now number one. Should we fire the preseason rankings committee?
mailbag.answer: The committee stands by its process — 40% win percentage, 30% points for, 20% recent form, 10% strength of schedule. The committee also acknowledges that Lamar Jackson, James Cook, and a random linebacker combining for 74.8 points was not in any model. The committee is reconvening.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: Father Time scored 165 and lost. MHJTIME scored 142 in Week 1 and lost. Is the Jailyard cursed?
mailbag.answer: It’s not cursed — it’s deeply, statistically cruel. Two teams have now scored 140-plus and lost in consecutive weeks. The chat should stop asking ‘what are the chances’ and start asking ‘who’s next.’

mailbag.question: @zbcowan asks: I was number one for exactly seven days. Is that a league record for shortest reign?
mailbag.answer: Unclear, but six spots in one week is a tumble that the chat will screenshot and resurface every August during preseason debates. One week you’re reading your essay out loud to Derrick Henry. The next, your kicker outscored your quarterback. The Giants didn’t just fall asleep — they hit snooze.

mailbag.question: Dear Commish: The picks column went 5-1 in Week 1. Should we just let the algorithm play our matchups?
mailbag.answer: A 5-1 debut is what we in the business call ‘unsustainable.’ The Noble FFT upset pick was the only miss, and Kittler made sure that one didn’t age well. We’ll ride the hot hand until reality catches up — which, given how Week 2 went, could be any minute.

mailbag.question: From the group chat: Five teams are 2-0 and five teams are 0-2. Is this actually just two separate leagues?
mailbag.answer: It’s the Jailyard’s clean split: the haves, the have-nots, and MHJTIME plus the Sleeping Giants sitting in the middle wondering how they ended up at 1-1 with completely different emotions about it. Give it two more weeks. The standings always get weird in October.

bits.title: Great Call of the Week
bits.text: Starting Daiyan Henley in IDP for the Boonist Monks. The linebacker put up 23.5 points — the third-highest scorer on a team that won by 69.9. Nobody in the group chat had Henley on their radar. @GauchoTrain did. That’s the difference between 2-0 and posting memes about ‘next year.’

bits.title: Parent Corner
bits.text: Somewhere a Sleeping Giants manager is explaining to their significant other why they’re upset about a fantasy football ranking dropping six spots. ‘But I was NUMBER ONE.’ ‘You’re number seven now?’ ‘My kicker outscored my quarterback.’ ‘...Is this going to affect dinner plans?’

bits.title: Is MHJTIME the New 2024 Sleeping Giants?
bits.text: Bear with me: loaded roster, league-leading point totals, a record that doesn’t match the production. The Sleeping Giants rode an aging core to the championship game last year despite the numbers not always cooperating. MHJTIME has the best two-week point total (325.4) and a .500 record. History says the points will start converting. Eventually.

bits.title: Overheard in the Chat
bits.text: ‘69.9-point margin should be illegal’ — @kharlow, who may have a point. ‘Henry scored 28.7 last week and didn’t crack the top five this week. The Giants are cooked.’ — anonymous, which in a twelve-person chat means everyone already knows who said it.

bits.title: Things I Believe But Can’t Prove
bits.text: Father Time is going to win four straight starting in Week 3. The roster is too talented and 285.7 total points at 0-2 is the kind of statistical anomaly that corrects violently. Book it — and then don’t blame me when it doesn’t happen.

picks.blurb: The first 2-0 vs. 2-0 showdown of the season, and it’s a beauty. The Monks have 313.1 total points and a 69.9-point blowout still fresh on the highlight reel. The Legion counters with Amon-Ra St. Brown’s 34.7-point eruption and McCaffrey’s steady floor. Lamar vs. the Voltron receivers. Monks by a nose — momentum is a real thing until it isn’t.

The defending champ’s consistency versus Rasheeing’s boom-or-bust RB cavalry. Jonathan Taylor’s 28.5 and Nacua’s 23.6 are repeatable ceilings; Allen being absent from the top five this week introduces a question mark for Rasheeing. Give the edge to the roster with fewer moving parts. Kittler grinds it out.

The 0-2 Bowl — someone has to win, and neither team is making a convincing case for why it should be them. Burden put up 98.8 last week; Ghastly managed 109.78. This is less a prediction and more a coin flip with extra steps. Give the slight edge to Ghastly’s younger core and hope C.J. Stroud remembers how to play quarterback.

Noble’s talent is too deep to stay at 0-2 for long, and Chudders’ rebuilding roster shouldn’t be the team that extends the drought. Bijan Robinson’s 18.3 and Jordan Love’s 20.88 represent a floor that Chudders can’t match yet. The preseason number two gets its first W here, and the group chat collectively exhales.

The marquee matchup of Week 3. MHJTIME has 325.4 total points — more than anyone — but a 1-1 record. General Ken-obi is 2-0 and ranked third. On paper, Ken-obi is the safer pick. But Nabers (34.2), Chase (30.5), and the highest-scoring week in the league’s young season don’t care about paper. Taking the upset. MHJTIME’s firepower is too hot to fade.

Two desperate teams with more talent than their records suggest. Father Time has 285.7 points at 0-2 — more than the 2-0 Rasheeing the Scene. The Sleeping Giants just lost their franchise player (Henry) from the top-five-scorers list and watched Jalen Hurts put up 10.54. The statistical correction starts here. Father Time gets the first win and silences approximately nobody in the chat.

special_picks.teaser: Boonist Monks +1.0 / Noble FFT -1.0 — the league’s hottest team and the most overdue bounce-back candidate, teased into near-gimmes
